rename.to: Some CompletableFuture assertion error message are confusing

issue.title: Add CompletionStage assertion

repository.name: assertj
repository.description: Fluent testing assertions for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
#### Summary
AbstractCompletableFutureAssert has methods to run assertions on CompletableFutures.
However, in any given unit test, the given CompletableFuture might not have completed yet, causing the test to be brittle. The exception report can be quite confusing because between the test  failure and the printing of the test error, the future might complete. So even a test asserting isDone() can fail with a message showing a done future.

Coding around this is ugly. Would be real nice if assertj had some waiting (with timeout, with default timeout) function embedded.

Also would be nice if this would work with CompletionStages as well.

Something like
```
CompletionStage<Foo> fooStage = getFoo();
assertThat(fooStage).completesWithin(1000).hasFailedWithThrowableThat()
```

Note: I think the awaitility library could also help, but so far did not use it. Could be this is better solved by using both awaitility and assertj.

issue.title: add brittle test with race condition

repository.name: assertj
repository.description: Fluent testing assertions for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
reproducing #1011 

Run the changed test. It repeats the same test 100 times. This fails for me like this:
```
mvn test -Dtest=CompletableFutureAssert_isCompletedExceptionally_Test

[ERROR]   CompletableFutureAssert_isCompletedExceptionally_Test.should_pass_if_completable_future_will_complete_exceptionally[88] 
Expecting
  <CompletableFuture[Incomplete]>
to be completed exceptionally


[ERROR]   CompletableFutureAssert_isCompletedExceptionally_Test.should_pass_if_completable_future_will_complete_exceptionally[89] 
Expecting
  <CompletableFuture[Failed: java.lang.RuntimeException]>
to be completed exceptionally
```

As you can see the first message makes sense, the future is incomplete. In the second case, the error says "expecting ... to be completed exceptionally, but it shows [Failed: java.lang.RuntimeException]"

Not sure if or how this can best be fixed, probably just a hint in the message might work.

body:
I created a PR with test to reproduce. Will think on how to improve. 

For the suggested improvement, still thinking. The current report example: 
```
[ERROR]   CompletableFutureAssert_isCompletedExceptionally_Test.should_pass_if_completable_future_will_complete_exceptionally[89] 
Expecting
  <CompletableFuture[Failed: java.lang.RuntimeException]>
to be completed exceptionally
```
should indicate that because this is an assert on a Future, the value shown may be different from the value that failed the assert. And this could include a suggestion to make the test stable by waiting for the async result before asserting.

I have not looked at the code causing this yet. Your analysis sounds fine. For the design of the message, I generally think the more information the better, if it can be presented in a non-confusing way.
Not showing the state would hide useful information in most cases. The race condition is an exceptional case.

A workaround would be to call toStringOf() before and after the check, and if the values differ, display them both somehow.

Else a hint that the displayed value might be updated should be good enough.

Interesting, I need to try the workaround to see if it can read nicely, if it does not then adding a warning like "be aware that the description of the future displayed here can different from the one at the moment the assertion was performed" as a the last line of  the end of the error message (if you have a better wording ... mine could certainly be improved)

I don't think it is possible to capture the future description and evaluate it atomically so the best that we can do is to add a warning in the error messages pertaining to future assertions or simply not to show the future state since it does not give reliable information.
@tkruse what would you prefer, no state information or state information + warning ?
I'd prefer the information and a warning / hint.

I'm going with `Be aware that the state of the future in this message might not reflect the one at the time when the assertion was performed as it is evaluated later on`, feel free to suggest a better wording if you have one.
